title: The Project Manager's Role
description: Understand the responsibilities and competencies of an effective project manager.
objectives: Understand the PM's three core responsibilities: Plan, Execute, Monitor & Control
Recognize the PM's authority boundaries (what they CAN control vs. what they CANNOT)
Apply the PMI Talent Triangle: Technical PM Skills, Leadership, Strategic & Business Management
Distinguish between authority (formal power) and influence (persuasion without power)

screens.headline: Alex's Question: What Can I Actually DECIDE?

visual.center: What IS the PM's actual authority?

dialogue.text: Carlos gave me the expansion project. But when I tried to approve the contractor, Elena said 'that's MY decision.' When I tried to add $10K to the budget, Carlos said 'you need MY approval.' What exactly CAN I decide?

screens.learningHook: PMs have RESPONSIBILITY for project success, but LIMITED AUTHORITY to make decisions. You must lead through INFLUENCE, not command.

screens.title: Authority Boundary Assessment
screens.instructions: For each scenario, decide if Alex has AUTHORITY to make the decision (can decide alone) or must RECOMMEND/REQUEST (needs approval).

scenarios.title: Project Charter Approval
description: Alex drafts the project charter for the restaurant expansion (purpose, objectives, high-level budget, timeline). It's ready for approval.

questions.question: Who approves the project charter and authorizes Alex to start the project?

options.text: Alex (PM approves own charter)
Carlos (Sponsor)
Elena (CFO)
Morgan (Product Owner)

feedback.correct: Perfect! The SPONSOR (Carlos) authorizes the project and approves the charter. PMs don't approve their own charters—that would be a conflict of interest.
feedback.incorrect: The SPONSOR authorizes the project. Alex drafts the charter, but Carlos must approve it. This formally gives Alex the authority to proceed.

scenarios.title: Daily Task Assignments
description: Alex's project team is working on site preparation. Excavation is behind schedule. Alex wants to reassign Taylor from permit paperwork to excavation support.

questions.question: Can Alex reassign Taylor to excavation?

options.text: Yes—Alex has authority to assign tasks within the project
No—Alex must ask Carlos (GM) for permission
No—Alex must ask Taylor's functional manager
No—Team self-organizes (Agile approach)

feedback.correct: Exactly! PMs have authority to assign and manage work WITHIN the project. Alex doesn't need approval for day-to-day task assignments.
feedback.incorrect: PMs have authority to assign tasks within the project scope. Requiring approval for every reassignment would be micromanagement.

scenarios.title: Budget Increase Request
description: Alex discovers permit costs are $15K higher than estimated ($30K vs. $15K budgeted). Total project budget is $850K. Alex wants to increase the budget.

questions.question: Can Alex approve a $15K budget increase?

options.text: Yes—Alex has authority to increase budget within project
No—Alex must request approval from Sponsor (Carlos) or CFO (Elena)
Yes, if Alex uses contingency reserve
No—Budget cannot be changed once approved

feedback.correct: Correct! PMs MANAGE the budget but don't APPROVE increases. Alex must request additional funding from Carlos or Elena.
feedback.incorrect: PMs don't approve budget increases. If PMs could increase budgets without approval, projects would spiral out of control.

scenarios.title: Team Conflict Resolution
description: Maya and Devon are arguing about construction sequencing. Maya: 'Do electrical first.' Devon: 'Plumbing first, it's safer.' The argument is delaying the schedule.

questions.question: What authority does Alex have to resolve the conflict?

options.text: Alex can ORDER a decision ('We're doing electrical first, end of discussion')
Alex must FACILITATE a decision (help Maya and Devon reach agreement)
Alex must escalate to Carlos to decide
Alex has no role (team resolves own conflicts)

feedback.correct: Perfect! PMs lead through INFLUENCE, not command. Alex should facilitate discussion, help evaluate options, and guide to consensus.
feedback.incorrect: Ordering a decision without team buy-in creates resentment. PMs should FACILITATE, helping the team reach consensus through collaboration.

scenarios.title: Vendor Selection (High-Value Contract)
description: Alex evaluates 3 construction contractors. Winner: Best Build Co. ($350K, excellent references, 4-month timeline). Alex wants to award the contract.

questions.question: Can Alex award the $350K contract to Best Build Co.?

options.text: Yes—Alex has authority to select vendors
Yes, but Alex must notify Carlos after signing
No—Alex RECOMMENDS vendor, Carlos (Sponsor) approves high-value contracts
No—Elena (CFO) must approve ALL contracts

feedback.correct: Exactly! PMs typically RECOMMEND vendors, but the SPONSOR approves high-value contracts. This protects the organization from conflicts of interest.
feedback.incorrect: For high-value contracts ($350K is significant), the sponsor must approve. Alex does the evaluation and recommends, Carlos decides.

gap.responsibility: PM is responsible for project SUCCESS (on time, on budget, meets scope)
gap.authority: PM has LIMITED formal authority (can't approve budgets, hire/fire, override sponsors)

whyGapExists: PMs don't own the resources (team members report to functional managers)
PMs don't control the budget (sponsor/CFO holds final approval)
PMs don't set strategic direction (sponsor defines objectives)

solution.name: Influence Without Authority
solution.definition: Getting people to take action WITHOUT commanding them

content.insight: Great PMs succeed NOT because they have power, but because they have INFLUENCE.

content.trend: PMI increasingly emphasizes Leadership and Strategic over pure Technical skills
content.pmbokRef: PMI Talent Triangle introduced in PMBOK 6th Ed

blocks.title: What the PM CAN Control vs. CANNOT Control

canControl: Task assignments (who works on what, when)
cannotControl: Scope changes that impact baseline (Change Control Board)
content.insight: Authority boundaries vary by organization. Alex must CLARIFY with Carlos: 'What decisions can I make alone?'

blocks.title: Dr. Amelia Foster's Advice—Leading Through Influence

framework.step: Build Relationships BEFORE you need them
framework.detail: Get to know stakeholders, understand their priorities, establish trust early
When asking for approval, explain WHY it matters to the business
Show stakeholders you're making their lives easier (clear reports, proactive risk management)
Instead of demands, present options aligned with goals

quote.text: Authority is GIVEN to you by your title. Influence is EARNED through your actions. The best PMs rely on influence, not authority.

correct.text: Correct. I'm accountable to the board for this expansion. I must approve the charter before you spend a dime, Alex.
Good to know. If I had to ask Carlos every time I reassigned someone, the project would grind to a halt.
Right. Alex can reallocate within the approved $850K budget. But adding more money? That's my decision.
Excellent, Alex. You're learning that influence beats authority. Help the team see the best path—don't dictate it.
I trust your evaluation, Alex. But for $350K, I need to sign off. It's my responsibility to the board.

screens.title: New Situation: Team Member Underperforming
screens.context: Liam (junior team member) is consistently missing deadlines. His work quality is poor. The team is frustrated. Alex needs to address this.

questions.question: What authority does Alex have regarding Liam's performance?

options.text: Alex can fire Liam (PM has authority over team)
Alex can formally discipline Liam (written warning)
Alex can provide feedback and coaching, but formal discipline requires functional manager approval
Alex has no authority (must escalate immediately to Carlos)

feedback.correct: Correct! In a matrix organization, PMs don't hire/fire. Alex CAN provide performance feedback and coaching. Formal discipline requires Liam's manager.
feedback.incorrect: PMs don't hire/fire team members. Alex can coach Liam, but formal discipline goes through the functional manager.

questions.question: Build Your Influence Strategy
questions.instruction: Select 4 elements Alex should use to coach Liam WITHOUT using command authority.

elements.label: Observation
elements.quote: I've noticed some challenges with your recent work...

elements.label: Inquiry
elements.quote: What's been blocking you from meeting deadlines?

elements.label: Support
elements.quote: How can I help remove obstacles for you?

elements.label: Impact
elements.quote: When deadlines slip, it affects the whole team's flow...

elements.label: Command
elements.quote: You must improve your performance immediately.

elements.label: Threat
elements.quote: If this continues, I'll have to escalate to Carlos.

feedback.correct: Perfect influence strategy! You chose empathetic, collaborative approaches that build trust.
feedback.partial: Good start, but avoid command/threat language. Influence is about understanding, not demanding.

questions.question: Coach the Conversation
questions.instruction: Practice the coaching conversation by selecting the best response at each turn.

turns.speaker: liam
turns.text: I know my work hasn't been great lately. I'm sorry.

options.text: I appreciate you acknowledging that. Help me understand what's been going on?
You're right to apologize. You need to do better.
The team is frustrated. What are you going to do about it?

turns.speaker: liam
turns.text: The new system has been confusing, and I've been struggling to keep up.

options.text: That's helpful to know. Would pairing you with Sofia for training help?
That's no excuse. Everyone else figured it out.
You should have asked for help earlier.

turns.speaker: liam
turns.text: That would actually help a lot. I was afraid to ask.

options.text: I'm glad you told me. Let's set up that training tomorrow. What else do you need?
Good. Don't let it happen again.
You should have spoken up sooner.

feedback.perfect: Excellent coaching! You used influence techniques throughout—inquiry, collaboration, and support.
feedback.partial: Good attempt, but remember: influence means understanding and supporting, not commanding or blaming.

screens.title: Key Takeaways
screens.summary: You've learned that PMs have RESPONSIBILITY for project success but LIMITED AUTHORITY. Great PMs lead through INFLUENCE.
takeaways: PM's Core Responsibilities: Plan, Execute, Monitor & Control
Authority Gap: Responsible for success, but can't approve budgets, hire/fire, override sponsors
Influence > Authority: Great PMs succeed through communication, negotiation, relationships
PMI Talent Triangle: Technical PM Skills + Leadership + Strategic & Business Management
Authority Boundaries: Clarify with sponsor—'What can I decide alone?'
Leading Through Influence: Build relationships, communicate Why, demonstrate value

artifacts.title: PM Authority Matrix
artifacts.description: Decision tree: 'Can I decide this, or need approval?'

characterClosing.text: Remember, Alex: Authority is GIVEN by your title. Influence is EARNED through your actions. Build influence every day—you'll need it.
